node.title: Chinese Tennis Star Accuses Politician of Assault, Social Media Account Then Deleted
node.description: "I was so frightened that afternoon, never thinking that this thing could happen," Peng's post said.

node.title: Netanyahu Won't Get Chance to Retake Leadership Position as Israel Avoids Snap Elections
node.description: "We will continue to fight this awful government.... We will look for any way to topple it, to return Israel to the right track," the ex-prime minister said.

node.title: Iran Burns American Flags, Hoists Joe Biden Effigy to Celebrate 1979 U.S. Embassy Takeover
node.description: Every year on the day that the U.S. Embassy takeover triggered a 444-day hostage crisis, Iranians rally to express their disapproval of relations with the U.S.

node.title: Oklahoma Governor Faces Pressure To Stop Julius Jones' Execution
node.description: Oklahoma's Pardon and Parole Board has twice voted to recommend Gov. Kevin Stitt commute Jones' sentence. His execution is scheduled for November 18.

node.title: Coalition member hits out at PM over Macron, climate change on Q+A
node.description: Greens leader Adam Bandt compares the Prime Minister's appearance at the COP26 summit to a "cigarette salesman in a cancer ward" as Scott Morrison's stoush with the French President is questioned by a fellow Coalition member.

node.title: 'Trajectory's not good': Great Barrier Reef bleaching study returns worrying results
node.description: Repeated bleaching events are reducing the Great Barrier Reef's ability to recover and scientists say the events must be viewed as interconnected.

node.title: Russian analyst who worked on Steele dossier arrested
node.description: Durham was been investigating the origins of the FBI's probe of former President Donald Trump's alleged links to Russia.

node.title: He Can’t Cure His Dad. But a Scientist’s Research May Help Everyone Else.
node.description: The muscle wasting disease that has debilitated Sharif Tabebordbar’s father motivated a life in science that led to an important medical discovery.

node.title: Big Donors Financed Biden’s 2020 Run. Now They Get a Chilly Reception.
node.description: Some of the top Democratic contributors have become increasingly frustrated with a lack of communication from the White House — and impatient with inaction on voting rights.

node.title: Only 1 Black Juror Is Chosen for Trial Over Ahmaud Arbery’s Killing
node.description: After a grueling selection process, opening statements in the case against three white men accused of chasing down and killing Mr. Arbery are expected to begin on Friday.

node.title: Armorer on 'Rust' Says She Inspected Rounds Before Giving Gun to Assistant Director
node.description: Reports indicated that investigators found more than 500 rounds of ammunition on the set. Law enforcement officials also seized a dozen revolvers and a rifle.

node.title: Every Female Senator Signs Letter Urging Biden to Do More to Protect Women in Afghanistan
node.description: "We will advise, support, and enable those efforts through legislation and engagement with your Administration," the senators stated.

node.title: As Police Reform Largely Loses Across U.S.,  A Defund The Police Activist Wins in Iowa
node.description: On Tuesday, Indira Sheumaker defeated two-term incumbent Bill Gray in Des Moines, as Iowa has become an increasingly Republican-controlled state.

node.title: Lindsey Graham Calls Trump 'Unpopular' as He Touts Republican Win in Virginia
node.description: Virginia GOP Governor-elect Glenn Youngkin distanced himself from the former president throughout his campaign.

node.title: Rittenhouse trial juror removed over joke about Jacob Blake shooting
node.description: Judge Bruce Schroeder said it was important to maintain public confidence in the case, and removing the juror was necessary.

node.title: ‘A Man Named Scott’ Review: Bending Genres, Coping With Struggles
node.description: This film about Kid Cudi is that rare musician-focused documentary, one as sensitive, fully formed and noble in its intentions as the artist himself.

node.title: ‘Finch’ Review: Three for the Road
node.description: Tom Hanks, a dog and two robots take a post-apocalyptic road trip in this unexciting drama from Apple TV+.

node.title: Man Eaten by Piranhas After Jumping in Lake to Flee From Bees
node.description: The man's body was found disfigured by piranhas who tore some parts of his body and his face, according to a local Brazilian news publication.

node.title: Businesses Could Face $136K Fine for Violating Biden Vaccine, Testing Mandate
node.description: OSHA will perform programmed inspections and follow up on claims about businesses not enforcing the vaccine or testing and mask-wearing mandate.

node.title: Vaccine Mandates Live Blog: Deadline Set For Employees at Large Companies
node.description: The Biden administration announced a new deadline for employees at large companies to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. Follow Newsweek's liveblog for all the latest.

node.title: U.S. Vaccine Mandate Takes Effect Jan. 4, Each Violation Could Cost Companies Almost $14K
node.description: Workers can alternatively get tested at least once weekly for the virus and must wear a mask in the workplace.

node.title: White House implementing business vaccine mandate and testing rules
node.description: The emergency standard stipulates that employers have to choose either full vaccination or weekly testing for their employees within 30 days and implement the mandate within 60 days.

node.title: Diwali festivities draw hundreds of thousands in India, despite Covid concerns.
node.description: More than 680,000 people have traveled across the country as health experts cautioned that large-scale gatherings might fuel a wave of infections.

node.title: The New York City Marathon Route: A Five-Borough Tour
node.description: The 26.2-mile race is a tour of New York City on foot, complete with roaring crowds scattered across diverse neighborhoods.

node.title: Annie Leibovitz, the Un-Fashion Photographer
node.description: “Fashion wasn’t anything I wanted to be involved with,” she says. Yet the visually arresting images in “Wonderland” may be her strongest work.

node.title: UK approves Merck's antiviral COVID pill in world first
node.description: Britain becomes the first country in the world to approve Merck's COVID-19 antiviral pill, molnupiravir.

node.title: Detroit decriminalizes psychedelic mushrooms
node.description: The substance, called psilocybin, can be used to treat a variety of psychological issues, including depression, although scientists​ are still doing research.

node.title: Remains of 2 sailors killed at Pearl Harbor in 1941 identified
node.description: Talbert and Collier were among 429 crewmen killed on the USS Oklahoma. Their remains were among many that could not be identified for decades.

node.title: Scientists create hybrid pumpkin to withstand climate change
node.description: Rising temperatures could result in less pumpkin production, threatening the livelihoods of U.S. farmers who rely on the seasonal crop.

node.title: Meryl Streep for President
node.description: Meryl Streep explains how she prepared to play a fictional (and not especially competent) U.S. president in Adam McKay’s apocalyptic satire “Don’t Look Up.”

node.title: After 14 Years, Robert Plant and Alison Krauss Finally Reunite
node.description: The duo worked with T Bone Burnett on the million-selling triumph “Raising Sand,” in 2007. Its sequel is once again an alternative to nearly all of its pop contemporaries.

node.title: ‘Tick, Tick … Boom!’: A Musical Based on a Musical About Writing a Musical. We Explain.
node.description: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s directorial debut is an adaptation of a show by Jonathan Larson, creator of “Rent.” This guide unpacks the many layers.

node.title: Longest uptick of new COVID vaccinations in months
node.description: The pace of first doses has climbed for eight straight days, the longest stretch since August.

node.title: Climate change protesters block roads outside British Parliament
node.description: Lawmakers have blasted the "Insulate Britain" activists for "interfering with democracy" after weeks of protests disrupting traffic, but the group is undeterred.

node.title: Hawaii is easing restrictions and preparing to welcome back tourists.
node.description: The state is eager for its vacation industry to rebound after a devastating 2020 season.

node.title: Mayor Eric Garcetti of Los Angeles tests positive for the virus.
node.description: Mr. Garcetti’s office said the mayor, who is in Scotland for a conference on climate change, was feeling good and had been fully vaccinated.

node.title: Authorities Arrest Analyst Who Contributed to Steele Dossier
node.description: Igor Danchenko, a Russia analyst who worked with Christopher Steele, the author of a dossier of rumors and unproven assertions about Donald J. Trump, was taken into custody as part of the Durham investigation.

node.title: The U.S. trade deficit rose as a surge of imports bogged down the supply chain.
node.description: The trade deficit in September climbed to $80.9 billion, a record. Imports rose slightly, while exports fell.

node.title: Man Accused of Taking Photos of Girls at Target Had Child Porn on Phone: Police
node.description: He was arrested after police received reports from mothers that a man was taking pictures their daughters.

node.title: Don't Trust Mark Zuckerberg's Metaverse With Your Privacy, ProtonMail CEO Warns
node.description: Andy Yen, who founded ProtonMail in 2014, said the metaverse is "insidious" and that the link between data and profit conflicts with Meta's promises on privacy.

node.title: HPV vaccines slash cervical cancer rates up to 87%, study finds
node.description: If more people get HPV vaccines and regular screenings, "cervical caner will become a rare disease," one of the study's authors says.

node.title: Realtor Works Out How Much The Simpsons' Home at 742 Evergreen Terrace Is Worth
node.description: The four-bedroom house in Springfield features an attic and a basement, and the secretive "rumpus room."

node.title: Tiger King's Joe Exotic says he has "aggressive cancer"
node.description: "Carole Will have her own party over this!" Joe Exotic wrote on Twitter, revealing his cancer diagnosis.

node.title: NT records first community transmission case of COVID-19
node.description: The Northern Territory's first ever case of COVID-19 community transmission will send Katherine into a lockdown and Greater Darwin into a lockout  for 72 hours as of midnight.

node.title: Tears of joy as little girl rescued 18 days after apparent abduction
node.description: Hope was fading after the 4-year-old vanished from her family's tent on a camping trip. When they found her, one senior officer said there wasn't "a dry eye in the house."

node.title: Jobless claims sink to new pandemic low
node.description: Roughly 269,000 Americans sought unemployment benefits last week, a sign the job market continues to heal.

node.title: Magic Johnson on getting HIV diagnosis in 1991: "I just lost it"
node.description: It's been 30 years since basketball legend Magic Johnson stunned the world when he announced he had HIV.

node.title: FBI releases declassified documents on probing Saudi ties to 9/11
node.description: Agents for years investigated support given to several of the hijackers, focusing on whether three Saudi nationals had advance knowledge of the attacks.

node.title: White House implementing business' vaccine mandate and testing rules
node.description: The emergency standard stipulates that employers have to choose either full vaccination or weekly testing for their employees within 30 days and implement the mandate within 60 days, sources tell CBS News.

node.title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
node.description: This week’s homes are a five-bedroom in Lloyd Neck, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Greenwich, Conn.

node.title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
node.description: This week’s properties are in Hell’s Kitchen and Sheepshead Bay, and on the Upper West Side.

node.title: How Californians Can Save More Water
node.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom has called for a 15 percent reduction in water usage, but we’re far from that target.

node.title: The Biden administration sets a Jan. 4 vaccination deadline for private sector workers.
node.description: The new guidance will cover 84 million workers, who will be required to be fully vaccinated or undergo weekly testing.

node.title: 3,000 Miles From Glasgow, a Town and Its Polar Bears Face the Future
node.description: In Churchill, climate change is not a looming danger. It imbues daily life.

node.title: ‘Dexter’ and the Shows That Wouldn’t Die
node.description: The revival of the serial-killer drama is TV’s latest refusal to let a supposedly finished franchise rest in peace.

node.title: $380,000 Homes in Alabama, Pennsylvania and Washington
node.description: A three-bedroom Tudor Revival-style home in Birmingham, an 1858 rowhouse in Philadelphia and a one-bedroom apartment in Seattle.

node.title: Walmart's Early Black Friday Event: The Best Homeware Deals on Kitchen Appliances, Vacuums and More
node.description: Bag early Black Friday discounts on homeware including an air fryer, the iRobot Roomba vacuum and other home goods.

node.title: Water, Vital Ingredient for Life, Found in Galaxy 13 Billion Light-Years Away
node.description: Studying the conditions of galaxies helps scientists to solve the mysteries of how stars, planets, and life evolved.

node.title: Over 8,000 Air Force Service Members Miss Vaccine Mandate Deadline
node.description: The Air Force said almost 97 percent of active-duty service members were at least partially vaccinated, while 800 had refused the shot. Almost 5,000 have pending religious exemption requests.

node.title: Australia among notable absences as dozens of nations pledge to phase out coal
node.description: More than 70 countries signed on to the deal at the COP26 climate summit in Scotland, but huge coal users and producers like Australia, China, India and the US are not on board.

node.title: Australia crushes Bangladesh to reignite World Cup hopes
node.description: Leg-spinner Adam Zampa takes five wickets as Australia decimate Bangladesh and put themselves in the drivers seat to make the semi-finals of the Twenty20 World Cup.

node.title: Judge declines to change racial makeup of jury in Arbery's death
node.description: Prosecutors had asked Superior Court Judge Timothy Walmsley to reinstate eight Black potential jurors, arguing that defense lawyers struck them from the final jury because of their race.

node.title: The U.K. approves Merck’s molnupiravir, making it the first pill to be endorsed for treating Covid.
node.description: The British authorities said that the antiviral drug was “safe and effective” in reducing the risk of hospitalization and death for those at increased risk of severe symptoms.

node.title: The Bank of England edges closer to rising interest rates, but holds steady.
node.description: Britain’s central bank said it would wait for more data on the labor market even as inflation is expected to climb to about 5 percent.

node.title: Liver donor, recipient running New York City Marathon together
node.description: Four years ago, Sara Kate Gillingham donated part of her liver to her friend Dave Kane. They see the race as a celebration of life and chance to raise awareness about organ donation.
